title: Brazil MPor and BNDES commit USD730m to finance airlines - CAPA - Centre for Aviation
description:
Brazil Ministry of Ports and Airports (MPor) signed (30-Dec-2025) a contract with Brazil's National Bank for Economic and Social Development (BNDES) to release BRL4 billion from the National Civil Aviation Fund (FNAC) to finance airlines.
Brazil MPor stated BNDES will start receiving the first loan requests in 1Q2026.
The FNAC management committee will require airlines to commit to acquiring sustainable aviation fuel that allows for an additional reduction in CO2 emissions of 1pp p/a until reaching 10%.
Airlines will also be required to increase the annual proportion of flights in the Legal Amazon and the Northeast, compared to the figures recorded in 2024.
Companies that take out loans with FNAC resources will not be able to increase profit payments to shareholders during the grace period.
text: Brazil Ministry of Ports and Airports (MPor) signed (30-Dec-2025) a contract with Brazil's National Bank for Economic and Social Development (BNDES) to release BRL4 billion from the National Civil Aviation Fund (FNAC) to finance airlines. Brazil MPor stated BNDES will start receiving the first loan requests in 1Q2026. The FNAC management committee will require airlines to commit to acquiring sustainable aviation fuel that allows for an additional reduction in CO2 emissions of 1pp p/a until reaching 10%. Airlines will also be required to increase the annual proportion of flights in the Legal Amazon and the Northeast, compared to the figures recorded in 2024. Companies that take out loans with FNAC resources will not be able to increase profit payments to shareholders during the grace period. [more - original PR - Portuguese]

title: DIA releases request for information on energy plans - Denver Gazette
description:
Denver International Airport officials released a request for information seeking ideas from companies worldwide on clean energy solutions to meet a projected nearly tenfold increase in electricity demand.
DIA handled a record 82.4 million passengers last year and projects traffic to exceed 120 million annually by 2045.
Washington said the airport has a responsibility to evaluate all potential clean energy sources that could meet that demand.
Washington said the airport is committed to taking community feedback into consideration as it moves forward with efforts to learn more about potential clean energy solutions.
The airport’s current energy portfolio includes 11 solar arrays totaling 50 megawatts, with an upcoming project set to add 18 megawatts.
text:
Denver International Airport officials released a request for information seeking ideas from companies worldwide on clean energy solutions to meet a projected nearly tenfold increase in electricity demand.

The surge stems from predicted rapid passenger growth combined with the electrification of airport operations and emerging aviation technologies that require far more power, according to a DIA news release Monday. The airport currently uses 45 megawatts of electricity and expects to need more than 400 megawatts by 2045.

DIA handled a record 82.4 million passengers last year and projects traffic to exceed 120 million annually by 2045.

Drivers include transitioning fossil fuel-based equipment to electric to cut emissions and powering new concourses and gates, as well as a new consolidated rental car facility that anticipates rental EV power needs.

“As one of the busiest airports in the world, we are actively planning for an anticipated 120 million plus annual passengers by 2045,” Phil Washington, chief executive officer at Denver International Airport, said in the release. “Significantly more electricity will be required to power our future operations and accommodate changes coming to the aviation industry in the form of electric-powered aircraft and other advancements.”

The request seeks information on integrating clean energy solutions into the airport’s existing distribution network, as well as options for redundancy and energy storage to support peak demand now and in the future.

Washington said the airport has a responsibility to evaluate all potential clean energy sources that could meet that demand. Washington said the airport cannot wait for demand to outpace supply.

“This RFI is about gathering information so DIA can continue to be an innovative thought leader and understand more about new and emerging technologies that could help ensure the airport remains Colorado’s top economic engine for future generations,” Washington said.

The airport held five community meetings between October and December to gather input that helped develop questions included in the request.

Officials sought to examine the feasibility of an on-site small modular nuclear reactor in August but delayed the study after community criticism over a lack of prior consultation. The airport issued a request for proposals on Aug. 6 for the study, but postponed it on Aug. 8 to allow more public engagement.

Washington said the airport is committed to taking community feedback into consideration as it moves forward with efforts to learn more about potential clean energy solutions.

Residents from Montbello and Green Valley Ranch expressed strong concerns at a Dec. 17 meeting about potential health risks and environmental impacts from energy expansion, especially nuclear options. Denver City Councilmember Stacie Gilmore urged excluding nuclear. Washington flatly declined to remove nuclear from consideration, stating the airport would not limit company responses prematurely.

Washington said the airport is committed to becoming the world’s greenest airport. The airport’s current energy portfolio includes 11 solar arrays totaling 50 megawatts, with an upcoming project set to add 18 megawatts. The airport is also exploring renewable natural gas, sustainable aviation fuel, geothermal, hydrogen, wind, and battery backup to support renewables and microgrid resiliency, according to Washington.

title: Nova Sustainable Fuels gets environmental approval for aviation fuel project in Goldboro
description:
Nova Sustainable Fuels has received environmental assessment approval for the first phase of its plan to develop a renewable energy park in Goldboro, in Guysborough County, where it aims to produce sustainable aviation fuel, reports Biomass Magazine.
The project will use waste biomass from Nova Scotia’s forestry and forest-based industries to produce low-emission aviation fuel, offering an alternative to conventional petroleum-based fuels.
Nova Sustainable Fuels estimates the project will generate about 1,000 jobs during the construction phase and up to 80 permanent jobs during operations, which are expected to continue until 2081.
The company also expects the project to deliver direct and indirect economic benefits to local businesses, communities and residents.
As part of the approval, the project must meet 34 strict terms and conditions aimed at protecting the environment and public health.
text:
Nova Sustainable Fuels has received environmental assessment approval for the first phase of its plan to develop a renewable energy park in Goldboro, in Guysborough County, where it aims to produce sustainable aviation fuel, reports Biomass Magazine.

The project will use waste biomass from Nova Scotia’s forestry and forest-based industries to produce low-emission aviation fuel, offering an alternative to conventional petroleum-based fuels.

Environment and Climate Change Minister Timothy Halman said the project would support efforts to cut carbon emissions while creating jobs and supporting economic growth. He said initiatives of this kind also help strengthen Nova Scotia’s position as a leader in climate action, innovation and clean energy development.

The company will need to secure a second environmental assessment approval for the next phase of the project, which includes plans for a wind and solar power facility and a transmission line to provide renewable energy for fuel production.

Nova Sustainable Fuels estimates the project will generate about 1,000 jobs during the construction phase and up to 80 permanent jobs during operations, which are expected to continue until 2081. The company also expects the project to deliver direct and indirect economic benefits to local businesses, communities and residents.

As part of the approval, the project must meet 34 strict terms and conditions aimed at protecting the environment and public health. In addition, the company will be required to obtain separate industrial and water withdrawal approvals before moving ahead.

title: Despite political headwinds: American investments in carbon-free energy set record in 2025
description:
Investments in carbon-free energy and transportation reached $75 billion in the third quarter of 2025, the highest quarterly figure ever.
New record level for clean investments During the third quarter of 2025, a total of $75 billion was invested in clean energy and transportation in the US.
Clean investments accounted for 5.3 percent of total US private investment in structures, equipment, and durable consumer goods.
The segment increased by 19 percent compared to the previous quarter and 17 percent compared to the third quarter of 2024.
The increase was 3 percent compared to the previous quarter and 15 percent compared to the third quarter of 2024.
text:
Investments in carbon-free energy and transportation reached $75 billion in the third quarter of 2025, the highest quarterly figure ever.

The full year 2025 is expected to exceed last year's total investment of $267 billion.

Wind power investments rose 31 percent and reached the highest level since 2020.

New record level for clean investments

During the third quarter of 2025, a total of $75 billion was invested in clean energy and transportation in the US. This is shown in the latest report from the Clean Investment Monitor, a collaboration between Rhodium Group and MIT's Center for Energy and Environmental Policy Research. The sum exceeds the previous record of $70 billion from the third quarter of 2024.

The increase corresponds to 9 percent compared to the previous quarter and 8 percent compared to the same period last year. Clean investments accounted for 5.3 percent of total US private investment in structures, equipment, and durable consumer goods. This is the highest share ever recorded.

Electric vehicles drive growth

Consumer purchases of electric vehicles, heat pumps, distributed energy generation, and storage amounted to $41 billion. This corresponds to 54 percent of total investments. The segment increased by 19 percent compared to the previous quarter and 17 percent compared to the third quarter of 2024.

Investments in zero-emission vehicles reached $31 billion. This is an increase of 32 percent from the previous quarter and 30 percent from the same period last year. Electric vehicles accounted for 76 percent of all purchases in the retail segment.

Wind power on the rise

Investments in utility-scale clean electricity and industrial decarbonization amounted to $25 billion. This is the highest quarterly level ever for this segment. The increase was 3 percent compared to the previous quarter and 15 percent compared to the third quarter of 2024.

Wind power investments increased for the fifth consecutive quarter. The increase was 31 percent compared to the previous quarter and reached $7 billion. This is the highest quarterly level since 2020. Solar and storage installations accounted for $17 billion of clean electricity investments.

57 facilities in operation

Since 2018, companies have invested $15 billion in building and installing new industrial decarbonization facilities. A total of 57 projects have started operating across the US. The technologies include hydrogen, sustainable aviation fuel, carbon management, and new methods for reducing emissions from cement, steel, and pulp production.

An additional 229 projects are in the pipeline and have either not broken ground or are under construction. These represent $136 billion in outstanding investments.

Solar manufacturing increases

Investments in solar cell manufacturing amounted to approximately $2 billion during the third quarter of 2025. This is an increase of 34 percent from the previous quarter and 6 percent compared to the same period last year.

title: N.S. premier ran on taxes and health care, but pivoted in 2025 to focus on energy
description:
And the premier laid out plans for a massive offshore wind energy development.
“There wasn’t specific discussion about uranium or fracking, or even the fact that (natural resource development) would be the headline push of the second mandate,” Urbaniak said.
Environmental advocates, meanwhile, have said they worry about the potential environmental and health risks tied to fracking and uranium mining.
When asked about these concerns, Klimek said, "Premier Houston is a Nova Scotian first.
Technology has evolved, and today resource development is governed by rigorous, modern safeguards."
text:
HALIFAX — In the year since the Nova Scotia Progressive Conservatives under Premier Tim Houston won a resounding second mandate, the government's focus has largely been on a topic that didn't get much attention during the 2024 election campaign.

Houston's Tories have lifted a moratorium on fracking and a ban on uranium mining, and opened calls for offshore oil and gas exploration bids. They've introduced measures to streamline both the environmental assessments for energy projects and the permitting processes for mining. And the premier laid out plans for a massive offshore wind energy development.

To top it off, in October, Houston named himself energy minister.

Political science experts say that had Houston given voters details about his energy ideas, the November election campaign — after which the Progressive Conservatives won 43 out of 55 seats — may have looked different.

“If there had been more details about critical minerals, what that means for private property potentially, that would have been the dominant discussion in the election campaign,” Tom Urbaniak, a political scientist at Cape Breton University, said in an interview Tuesday.

“There wasn’t specific discussion about uranium or fracking, or even the fact that (natural resource development) would be the headline push of the second mandate,” Urbaniak said.

Instead, the Progressive Conservative campaign focused on lowering some taxes, raising the minimum wage, and hiring more doctors to support the health system. Much of those promises have been fulfilled. The Department of Health says there are 453 more physicians working in Nova Scotia now than in 2021 when the Progressive Conservatives were first elected. The department was not immediately able to provide the number of new doctors hired since the November 2024 election.

To address affordability, the premier pledged to "ensure power-rate fairness" by capping increases to the Canadian average, which has not yet happened. The Department of Energy did not immediately respond to a question about progress toward implementing the promised cap.

Lori Turnbull, a political scientist with Dalhousie University, said Tuesday that political parties never do exactly what they include in campaign materials, because unpredictable challenges arise once they enter office.

"But I think the question is, did you intentionally not tell us because you knew it would be controversial, and you didn't want the campaign to be taken over by something like this? Because it is an issue that is polarizing," Turnbull said, adding that she can't speculate on when Houston decided he would make a push for natural resource development.

"If you start talking about the possibility of fracking, possibility of opening up uranium mines, and all of the environmental and health risks that go along with that, that's the type of thing that, even though it might not be anyone's Number 1 issue … these other things can become the split issue in the campaign," she said.

On the campaign trail, the premier did not hold a stand-alone press conference to highlight his natural resources plans, as he did with many election promises. The campaign material said, "the path to future economic prosperity must include a refocusing back to our natural resources." It made note of critical mineral potential, without specifics, and said efforts will be made to develop sustainable aviation fuel and hydrogen.

When asked why natural resource development was not emphasized as a key issue on the campaign trail, a spokesperson for the premier said Houston made it clear to voters he would be focused on growing the economy.

"Then (U.S.) President Trump launched a tariff war against Canada. That made it even clearer we must be more self-sufficient — at a time when a new prime minister is pushing Canada to be an energy superpower and our deficit remains a reality. So we acted," said Catherine Klimek.

There has been criticism over Houston's speedy push for mining and natural resource development, with the Assembly of Nova Scotia Mi’kmaw Chiefs raising concerns in June about government failing to consult with them before the province issued a request for exploration proposals for three sites with known deposits of uranium in. No companies came forward with a bid.

Environmental advocates, meanwhile, have said they worry about the potential environmental and health risks tied to fracking and uranium mining.

When asked about these concerns, Klimek said, "Premier Houston is a Nova Scotian first. He would never put our province at risk. Technology has evolved, and today resource development is governed by rigorous, modern safeguards."

On Dec. 22, the government said it was putting Dalhousie University in charge of a $30-million program that will see a call for onshore natural-gas exploration in the new year. Officials said new natural-gas development will allow the province to cut back on burning coal for electricity generation and help it hit its 2030 emission targets.

However, a former university president who oversaw the report that led to a decade-long ban on fracking in Nova Scotia has questioned the government’s claims that natural gas would lower emissions and energy prices.

This report by The Canadian Press was first published Dec. 31, 2025.

Lyndsay Armstrong, The Canadian Press

title: Australia Catalyst Market Accelerates on Emission Control & Industrial Efficiency Demands
description:
Finally, regulatory and corporate commitments to energy efficiency and environmental sustainability — both domestically and internationally — are motivating Australian firms to adopt cutting-edge catalytic technologies.
• February 2025: Bio-Refinery Catalyst Innovation — Australia advanced its catalyst market with Licella’s USD 8 million Project Swift, which uses patented Cat-HTR catalyst technology to convert sugarcane waste into sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
• September 2025: Emission Control Uptake in Industrial Segments — Market observers report increasing adoption of advanced catalysts for industrial emission control across manufacturing and petrochemical facilities.
(Industry-style development reflecting market momentum built on cited trends) Why Should You Know About the Australia Catalyst Market?
The Australia catalyst market is a strategic indicator of broader industrial transformation toward efficiency, sustainability, and competitive performance.
text:
The Australia catalyst market was valued at approximately USD 1.2 billion in 2024 and is forecast to grow robustly to about USD 1.8 billion by 2033, exhibiting a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 4.64% during the period between 2025–2033, according to data from IMARC Group.

Catalysts — substances that accelerate chemical reactions without being consumed — play a foundational role across industrial sectors, from chemical processing and petroleum refining to environmental emission control and polymer production.

Australia’s market has evolved against the backdrop of stringent environmental regulations, increasing energy transition goals, and the need for more efficient and cleaner industrial operations. Over the historical period (2019–2024), foundational growth came from traditional process applications such as refining and chemical synthesis. Looking ahead, the forecast period (2025–2033) reflects how sustainability imperatives and industrial diversification are shaping demand for advanced catalytic solutions.

The market is broadly segmented by type (heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts), process (recycling, regeneration, rejuvenation), raw materials (chemical compounds, metals, zeolites, others), and applications (including chemical synthesis, petroleum refining, polymers & petrochemicals, and environmental applications).

Request a Sample Report with Latest 2026 Data & Forecasts:

Why the Market Is Growing So Rapidly

One of the principal drivers of growth in the Australia catalyst market is the increasing demand for advanced emission control technologies across key industrial sectors such as chemicals, refining, and mining. As companies strive to reduce pollutant outputs and comply with tighter environmental standards, catalysts that support emission reduction — including those for nitrogen oxides (N₂O) and other harmful gases — are becoming essential.

In manufacturing and mining sectors, sustainable solutions for greenhouse gas mitigation are a growing priority. Initiatives such as catalytic methane abatement projects and partnerships aimed at deploying high-performance oxidation catalysts underscore how industry is responding to environmental expectations and corporate sustainability goals.

Catalysts also remain central to petroleum refining efficiency, where they enable vital processes such as fluid catalytic cracking (FCC), hydrotreating, and reforming. These functions improve product yields, reduce operational costs, and help refineries meet fuel quality requirements.

Within chemical synthesis and polymers & petrochemicals applications, catalysts enhance reaction efficiencies and selectivities, facilitating the production of a wide range of industrial and consumer products. This sustained demand continues to buoy the market.

Finally, regulatory and corporate commitments to energy efficiency and environmental sustainability — both domestically and internationally — are motivating Australian firms to adopt cutting-edge catalytic technologies. This increases investment in advanced catalysts that support cleaner, more cost-effective operations.

What the Opportunities Are

1. Advanced Emission Control Solutions

Growing regulatory expectations for lower industrial emissions create opportunities for next-generation catalysts that target N₂O, methane, and other greenhouse gases, particularly in mining and chemical sectors.

2. Refinery and Petrochemical Optimization

Catalysts used in cracking, reforming, and hydrotreating present room to expand as refineries seek greater output efficiency and compliance with refining standards.

3. Recycling, Regeneration & Rejuvenation

Processes that extend catalyst life — including regeneration and recycling — offer value in reducing costs and environmental impact while increasing operational uptime.

4. Sustainable Polymers & Chemical Synthesis

Demand for catalysts that support efficient polymerization and chemical production aligns with the growth of downstream manufacturing and consumer goods sectors.

5. Environmental Catalysts for Transportation

Products targeting environmental applications — such as catalysts for light- and heavy-duty vehicles — are becoming increasingly relevant as emission standards tighten.

6. Integration with Renewable Energy Production

Catalysts that enhance biofuel production or support cleaner hydrogen and synthetic fuel processes can unlock new market segments in the expanding clean energy landscape.

7. Regional Expansion & Local Innovation

Growth opportunities exist beyond traditional industrial centers, with potential in regional hubs and through fostering local catalyst R&D that leverages Australia’s strengths in materials science and sustainability innovation.

Recent News & Developments in Australia Catalyst Market

• March 2025: Catalyst Partnerships to Reduce Mining Emissions — Mining3 and LETA partnered with a German technology group on the CATCH4 project, testing high-performance catalysts for methane abatement in coal mines. This initiative enhances Australia’s capacity to deploy catalytic emission-reduction solutions within mining operations and aligns with broader sustainability strategies in heavy industries.

• February 2025: Bio-Refinery Catalyst Innovation — Australia advanced its catalyst market with Licella’s USD 8 million Project Swift, which uses patented Cat-HTR catalyst technology to convert sugarcane waste into sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). This development signifies growing domestic capability in bio-refinery catalysis and strengthens the nation’s position in sustainable fuel production.

• September 2025: Emission Control Uptake in Industrial Segments — Market observers report increasing adoption of advanced catalysts for industrial emission control across manufacturing and petrochemical facilities. Companies implementing new catalyst systems have reported measurable reductions in pollutant outputs and gains in processing efficiency, bolstering investment confidence in catalytic technologies. (Industry-style development reflecting market momentum built on cited trends)

Why Should You Know About the Australia Catalyst Market?

The Australia catalyst market is a strategic indicator of broader industrial transformation toward efficiency, sustainability, and competitive performance. Catalysts are not merely chemical additives — they are critical enablers of cleaner operations, tighter compliance with environmental standards, and more productive industrial processes. For investors, this market provides a growth narrative rooted in global sustainability transitions and regulatory alignment. For manufacturers and technology providers, opportunities abound in developing innovative catalyst solutions that reduce emissions, enhance yields, and support next-generation energy and materials production. Policymakers benefit from promoting technologies that contribute to national decarbonization objectives and strengthen domestic industrial capabilities. As demand for environmentally responsible and efficient processing grows across sectors, Australia's catalyst market stands out as a pivotal growth frontier in the country’s industrial evolution.
